newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end mostly up on LME gains.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end mostly up on LME gains.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended mostly up in active trading on Friday on continued gains on the London Metal Exchange (LME) but local contracts still met strong resistance at the 24,000-yuan level, traders said.
The most actively traded September 1997 contract ended at 23,920 yuan ($2,884) per tonne, rising 40 yuan.
It opened at 23,950 yuan per tonne, hitting an intraday high of 24,140 yuan and a low of 23,870 yuan per tonne.
June fell 20 to 23,350. July rose 20 to 23,620, August 30 to 23,760, October 40 to 23,900 and November 90 to 23,900 yuan.
Combined volume rose to 76,340 tonnes from 65,600 tonne.
LME three months copper was indicated at $2,507/10 per tonne at 1800 GMT on Thursday, and London traders said it set to consolidate around $2,500 a tonne on Friday.
Shanghai copper opened high and rose further for most of the session before profit-taking pushed prices down in late trade.
Traders said investors held different views on the short-term market trend, and that was behind Friday fluctuations.
"Copper breached the key 24,000-yuan level in the morning but it closed below the level, indicating there was strong selling pressure," one trader said.
"Active trading suggested investors disagreed with each other on the short-term market trend," he added. "This might lead to further price volatility in the next few days."
Physical price indications in the Shanghai area strengthened through the day to around 23,350 yuan from 23,100 yuan.
Traders said domestic fundamentals had changed little but technical charts indicated copper was likely to rise further in the next few days.
"Recent trading has indicated long and short position holders will fight fiercely around the 24,000-yuan level in the next few days," a second trader said.
Aluminium ended down. June did not trade, July fell 100 to 15,500 and August 20 to 15,770 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume fell to 420 tonnes from 1,110 tonnes.
